Part A: Describe one cause of the advance in Black political representation evident in the excerpt.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Black Freedom movement had an impact on Black political representation in the 1960s by increasing the number of Black elected officials.

  • The Congressional Black Caucus promoted Black political power and supported Black candidates in national, state, and local elections.

  • Black political representation led to an increase in the number of African Americans who participated in the political process.

  • The Voting Rights Act of 1965 removed racial segregation barriers that prevented African Americans from participating in voting.

  • Civil Rights activists challenged discriminatory practices in voting through nonviolent campaigns such as the Mississippi Freedom Summer Project.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Describe one specific example of Black political leadership before 2004.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Shirley Chisholm became the first Black woman elected to Congress in 1968.

  • In 2001, Colin Powell became the first Black secretary of state.

  • Hiram Revels was the first Black person elected to the Senate.

  • James Rapier was elected to Congress after the Civil War.

Part C: Explain how the author’s life experience may have influenced his description of the United States.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The author’s perspective was likely influenced by desegregation in the 1950s and 1960s, which expanded educational opportunities for people like him. This experience may have contributed to his optimism about the United States.

  • As the son of an African immigrant, he viewed the United States as the land of opportunity.

  • The author’s focus on equality and inalienable rights was likely shaped by his experiences as a Black person living in a country with a history of racial discrimination.

Part D: Explain how economic growth in Black communities was hindered or promoted in the second half of the twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Racial discrimination in employment in the early twentieth century limited Black communities’ accumulation of generational wealth.

  • Racial disparities in housing limited Black communities’ accumulation of generational wealth.

  • Desegregation gradually increased the number of Black college graduates, which contributed to the growth of the Black middle class.

  • Urbanization increased opportunities for employment and the growth of Black businesses.
